Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Neil.

text: And I'm Rob.
Now, Rob, would you say that you are an introvert or an extrovert?
speaker: Neil

text: Hmm, what a good question.
Well, extroverts are confident in their personality,
their outgoing and comfortable in social situations.
So I would have to say that if anything, I'm the opposite.
I'm more of an introvert, I'm really quite shy.
I feel uncomfortable in social situations.
For example, if I go to a party where I don't know anyone,
I usually feel very embarrassed and I find it impossible
to start conversations with strangers.
But you do all of this on the radio and videos
speaker: Neil

text: for BBC Learning English, don't you?
Some would say you have to be an extrovert to do what we do.
Oh, well, maybe I'm pretending to be an extrovert.
To hide the fact that I'm an introvert, it's quite a common thing, you know.
Well, it might not be so easy to hide in the future
speaker: Neil

text: because researchers have developed a computer program
that can tell your personality from looking at where you look
by tracking your eye movements.
Wow, that sounds pretty high-tech and scary.
Well, weâ€™ll learn more shortly,
speaker: Neil

text: But first, a question on the topic of clever computers.
The letters AI stand for artificial intelligence.
But what are the letters AI?
Are they A, an abbreviation, B, an acronym, or C, an initialism?
Okay, I thought that was going to be easy,
but I think it's an abbreviation, isn't it?
speaker: Neil

text: Well, you'll have to wait until the end of the program to find out.
Sabrina Hopper is a researcher at the University of Stuttgart.
She was interviewed on the BBC Radio program all in the mind.
She spoke about an experiment in which they tracked the eye movements
speaker: Neil

text: of people in real situations.
This is what she said about the research.
Was she confident the experiment would work in the real world?
The main finding in our study is that it's possible at all
to just look at eye movements and then predict something about their personality.
speaker: finding

text: And before our study, it was not clear at all
if this would be possible from eye movements
in such an unconstrained real-world setting.
So, was she confident this would work?
speaker: Neil

text: No, not really.
She said that before the study, it wasn't clear
if it would be possible in an unconstrained real-world setting.
Unconstrained here means that there wasn't strict control
over the conditions of the experiment.
It took place in the real world, so not in a laboratory.
The result of the experiment or the finding, as she called it,
was that by following eye movements,
a computer program was able to work out the personality of the subjects.
Let's listen again.
The main finding in our study is that it's possible at all
to just look at eye movements and then predict something about their personality.
And before our study, it was not clear at all
if this would be possible from eye movements
in such an unconstrained real-world setting.
So how does the software work, for example,
speaker: extrovertsintroverts

text: What are the differences in the eye movements of extroverts compared to introverts?
We still don't really know in detail what makes the difference.
We can only tell that there are differences and that we know
computer programs that can pick up those differences.
Maybe extrovert people look up a lot because they want to look at people's faces,
whereas some super introvert person maybe just dares at their own shoes
if you want to take the extreme examples.
So probably it somehow changes case,
but we only know that this information is there
and somehow our program figured out how to extract it.
So how does it work?
speaker: Neil

text: Well, that's the strange thing.
She said that she didn't really know, at least not in detail.
She did say that our personality somehow changes gaze.
Gaze is another word for looking at something.
So maybe we gaze in different ways,
depending on our personality.
Extroverts may look up more,
and introverts like me may look down more.
Yes, it was interesting that she said that she didnâ€™t know how it did it,

means to understand or realize something.
Time to review today's vocabulary.
But first, let's have the answer to the quiz question.

Rob, what did you say

. Well sorry, no

text: A-I is C, so to speak.
It's an initialism.
It's the first letters of the words artificial intelligence,
but it's not pronounced like a new word, just the initial letters.
Right, time now to review today's vocabulary.
Yes. We had the word extrovert.
speaker: extrovertextrovert

text: This describes someone who has a very outgoing personality.
An extrovert is confident and socially comfortable.
By contrast, an introvert is someone who is shy
and not comfortable in social situations
and doesn't like being the center of attention.
Our report today talked about the findings of some new research.
speaker: findingsfinding

text: A finding is something that has been learned,
discovered, or indeed found out.
It is the conclusion that is reached.
Then we had unconstrained to describe the experiment
which was not carried out in a controlled environment.
So unconstrained means not limited or restricted.
Our next word was gaze.
speaker: gaze

text: This is a word that means our way of looking at something.
Yes, the findings of the research
suggest that our personality can affect our gaze.
And this was something the computer was able to figure out.
speaker: tofigure outTo figure out

text: To figure out means to study something
and reach an answer to a particular question or problem.
